column2: Why does the least squares regression line minimize the sum of squared residuals rather than the sum of absolute residuals?
column3: Squaring eliminates negative values and has desirable mathematical properties for calculus
column4: Absolute values are too difficult to calculate without modern computing technology
column5: Squared residuals always produce a line through the origin of the coordinate system
column6: The sum of absolute residuals would give equal weight to all data points

column2: When comparing two linear models for the same dataset, Model A has a sum of residuals of 0 and Model B has a sum of residuals of 0. What can we conclude?
column3: Both models are equally good fits because their residual sums are identical
column4: Neither conclusion is valid without examining the squared residuals instead
column5: Model A must be better because it was mentioned first in the comparison
column6: The models are identical lines because only one line has zero residual sum

column2: For three perfectly collinear points, why might a poorly fitting line still have a sum of residuals equal to zero?
column3: Positive and negative residuals can cancel each other out algebraically
column4: Collinear points automatically produce zero residuals for any fitted line
column5: The calculation method for residuals changes when points are collinear
column6: Three points always define a unique line with zero total deviation

column2: The least squares regression line for a dataset always passes through which point?
column3: The point with coordinates (x̄, ȳ) where bars indicate means
column4: The first data point that was collected in the original sample
column5: The median values of both the explanatory and response variables
column6: The point that minimizes the distance to all other data points

column2: If a dataset has x̄ = 42.5 and ȳ = 18.3, which point must lie on the LSRL?
column3: (42.5, 18.3) because the regression line contains the mean point
column4: (18.3, 42.5) because the coordinates can be reversed for linearity
column5: (30.4, 30.4) because this represents the average of both means
column6: (0, 60.8) because this is the y-intercept plus both means

column2: What does minimizing the sum of squared residuals accomplish in regression analysis?
column3: It finds the line that best balances prediction errors across all data points
column4: It ensures that exactly half of the residuals will be positive values
column5: It guarantees that the correlation coefficient will be maximized
column6: It forces the regression line to pass through every data point

column2: Two students fit lines to the same data. Student A's line has Σ(residuals)² = 145. Student B's line has Σ(residuals)² = 132. Which is the better model?
column3: Student B's model because it has the smaller sum of squared residuals
column4: Student A's model because larger squared residuals indicate stronger fit
column5: Neither model is better without knowing the correlation coefficient
column6: Both models are equivalent since they use the same dataset

column2: Given correlation r = 0.8, sy = 12, and sx = 4, what is the slope of the LSRL?
column3: b = 2.4 because slope equals correlation times ratio of standard deviations
column4: b = 0.267 because slope equals correlation divided by ratio of standard deviations
column5: b = 3.75 because slope equals sum of standard deviations times correlation
column6: b = 38.4 because slope equals product of all three given values

column2: If the LSRL equation is ŷ = 15 + 3x, what is the predicted change in y when x increases by 2 units?
column3: The predicted y value increases by 6 units based on the slope coefficient
column4: The predicted y value increases by 21 units including the intercept effect
column5: The predicted y value increases by 3 units regardless of the change in x
column6: The predicted y value increases by 30 units after doubling all terms

column2: For the regression equation ŷ = -8.5 + 1.2x predicting test scores from hours studied, interpret the slope.
column3: Each additional hour studied predicts an average 1.2 point increase in score
column4: Students who don't study are predicted to score negative 8.5 points
column5: The correlation between hours studied and test score equals 1.2
column6: Test scores increase by 8.5 points for every 1.2 hours studied

column2: When is the y-intercept of a regression line meaningful in context?
column3: When the explanatory variable can reasonably take the value zero
column4: When the response variable has only positive values in the dataset
column5: When the correlation coefficient is greater than 0.7 in magnitude
column6: When all data points are located in the first quadrant only

column2: A regression predicting weight from height has y-intercept -200 pounds. Why is this not meaningful?
column3: A height of zero inches is not realistic for the context being studied
column4: Negative weights are impossible indicating an error in calculation
column5: The y-intercept should always be positive in biological contexts
column6: The regression line must pass through the origin for height-weight data

column2: If correlation r = -0.6 and the ratio sy/sx = 5, what is the slope of the LSRL?
column3: b = -3.0 because slope equals correlation times the ratio of standard deviations
column4: b = -0.12 because slope equals correlation divided by the ratio of standard deviations
column5: b = 3.0 because slope magnitude ignores the sign of the correlation
column6: b = -8.33 because slope equals the ratio divided by correlation

column2: The LSRL for predicting final exam score from homework average is ŷ = 45 + 0.5x. If homework average is 80, what is the predicted exam score?
column3: 85 points as calculated by substituting the homework value into the equation
column4: 125.5 points by adding all numerical values in the problem together
column5: 40 points representing half of the homework average as indicated by slope
column6: 45.5 points by adding the slope to the intercept value directly

column2: If the correlation between two variables is r = 0.9, what is R²?
column3: 0.81 because the coefficient of determination equals correlation squared
column4: 0.95 because the coefficient of determination equals square root of correlation
column5: 0.90 because the coefficient of determination equals the correlation itself
column6: 1.81 because the coefficient of determination equals correlation plus itself

column2: An R² value of 0.64 means what percentage of variation in y is explained by the linear relationship with x?
column3: 64% of the variation in the response variable is explained by the model
column4: 36% of the variation in the response variable is explained by the model
column5: 80% of the variation in the response variable is explained by the model
column6: 8% of the variation in the response variable is explained by the model

column2: If R² = 0.49, what are the possible values for the correlation r?
column3: r = 0.7 or r = -0.7 because correlation is the square root of R²
column4: r = 0.49 only because correlation and R² are the same value
column5: r = 0.24 or r = -0.24 because correlation is half of R²
column6: r = 0.7 only because correlation cannot be negative with positive R²

column2: What does it mean when comparing a 'mean model' to the LSRL for calculating R²?
column3: The mean model predicts ȳ for all values while LSRL uses x to predict
column4: The mean model uses the median while LSRL uses the average of all points
column5: The mean model includes all variables while LSRL uses only significant ones
column6: The mean model weights observations equally while LSRL weights by distance

column2: A regression has R² = 0.15. What does this suggest about the linear relationship?
column3: The linear relationship is weak with most variation unexplained by the model
column4: The linear relationship is strong but the data has high natural variability
column5: The calculation is incorrect because R² must be at least 0.50
column6: The variables have no relationship because R² is less than one

column2: How is R² related to the reduction in sum of squared residuals?
column3: R² represents the percent reduction from the mean model to the LSRL model
column4: R² represents the absolute reduction in residuals between any two models
column5: R² represents the ratio of residuals to the total number of observations
column6: R² represents the sum of all positive residuals in the final model

column2: In computer output for regression, where is the slope coefficient typically found?
column3: As the coefficient of the explanatory variable in the regression table
column4: As the constant or intercept term in the regression table
column5: As the R² value in the model summary statistics section
column6: As the standard error of the regression in the output

column2: Computer output shows: Constant = 25.3, StudyHours coefficient = 4.2, R² = 0.72. What is the regression equation?
column3: ŷ = 25.3 + 4.2x where x represents study hours
column4: ŷ = 4.2 + 25.3x where x represents study hours
column5: ŷ = 0.72 + 29.5x combining all numerical values
column6: ŷ = 72 + 25.3x using percentage form of R²

column2: If computer output shows a negative slope coefficient and R² = 0.36, what is the correlation?
column3: r = -0.6 because the negative slope indicates negative correlation
column4: r = 0.6 because correlation is always positive when calculated
column5: r = -0.36 because correlation equals R² with the slope's sign
column6: r = -0.13 because correlation is R² divided by slope coefficient

column2: A regression of price on square footage shows: Intercept = 50000, Slope = 125, R² = 0.85. Interpret the slope.
column3: Each additional square foot predicts an average price increase of $125
column4: Houses with no square footage are predicted to cost $50000
column5: The correlation between square footage and price equals 0.85
column6: Square footage explains $125 worth of price variation

column2: When reading computer output, how can you determine if the correlation is positive or negative?
column3: Check the sign of the slope coefficient for the explanatory variable
column4: Check whether R² is greater than or less than 0.5
column5: Check the sign of the intercept term in the regression equation
column6: Check whether the standard error is positive or negative
